job_title: Anonymous Employee in New Rochelle, NY
pros: Dedicated Instructors overall. Many of the staff and administrators are fabulous. Students at large are amazing people and truly want to change the world.
cons:
Staff assessments are too quantified and not relevant for all departments. They are tied to raises, however, so you'd better "measure up." Going through the assessment process feels like you're forced into limiting boxes and is an excruciating experience. You are also limited to viewing yourself as a "3" which is average (out of 5) on all positive counts unless you perform miracles. 

Your evenings and weekends are only half your own. The other half belongs to open houses, student welcome day, freshman orientations, Homecoming weekend coverage, etc., etc., etc., etc. This is true no matter your area of employment - all are expected to participate.

Salaries, for what is asked of you, are low.

job_title: Clinical Lecturer I in New Rochelle, NY
pros: Small class sizes; real knowledge of student population. Manageable and attractive campus. Launch of new School of Arts and Sciences. Strong alumni commitment.
cons: Salary is below average national salaries. Significant turnover in Provosts, resulting in directional shifts in leadership.

job_title: Supervisor in New Rochelle, NY
pros: Hours were flexible. Supervisor was understanding.
cons: The pay could have been better.

job_title: Staff Accountant in New Rochelle, NY
pros: Tuitikn reimbursement. Free parking, 3 free drinks
cons: No place for moving up.

job_title: Student Assistant in New Rochelle, NY
pros: Convenient for current students to work with student employment especially those who live on campus

job_title: Assistant Director in New York, NY

job_title: Office Assistant in New Rochelle, NY

job_title: Student Financial Services in New Rochelle, NY
pros: After 3 months of full-time employment (some departments are notorious for not converting their temp employees), you are eligible for free undergraduate tuition and taxable graduate tuition.  The work/life balance is great, especially for FLSA non-exempt employees, but that might be mostly because they hate to pay overtime.  It was a good place to sharpen technical skills while going to school.
cons: The pay is downright awful.  There is a lot of politicking that prevents some improvements, and management can be a little overbearing sometimes.  I never had any personal grief with other departments, but I have heard of several people having a difficult time with HR.

review_title: I really enjoyed my experience at Iona College.  Met a lot of great people and learned a lot.
job_title: in New Rochelle, NY
pros: Great hours, great people.  Really enjoyed working with the students.  A lot of multi-tasking which I enjoyed.  Great benefits as well.
cons: The pay isn't the best, but the benefits will help ease that pain.  There really isn't much potential for growth.

job_title: Graduate Assistant in New Rochelle, NY
pros: The people and staff there are all very nice. I felt like I was able to contribute and be heard. Overall, the environment was pretty relaxed most of the time but obviously there is more to do at the beginning of the semester.
cons: Finding information regarding administrative stuff can be like a game of email and phone tag sometimes. It  is important to figure out who knows the procedures and talk to them directly.

job_title: Student Affairs Administrator in New Rochelle, NY
pros: Small, student-centered and people-centered environment with ample oppurtunities for professional development and exploration; "family" feel
cons: Iona's administrative procedures are still largely conducted on paper with many staff/administrators expressing fear at "trusting" technology leading to a highly ineffective structure. Administrative functions are highly restricted when technology is utilized. Staff is often thanked for working for less money than they deserve and have repeatedly been promised a salary review, but their is no senior leadership commitment to address income disparity.

job_title: Director in Purchase, NY
pros: The small academic community is very collaborative. Faculty have advanced degrees and have professional experience in the areas that they teach. Administrative staff and faculty work together to support students and the college's initiatives.
cons: As a small school there are only a few large or well known employers that will recruit students  from Iona. The selection of candidates is relatively small for these employers who can meet greater numbers of candidates at larger institutions.

job_title: in Yonkers, NY
pros: Excellent school to work in the students were respectful and the faculty were nice. Iona is the best school in westchester ever...........I wish
cons: An academic organization in the tradition of the Christian Brothers and American Catholic higher education located in New Rochelle, NY.

job_title: in New Rochelle, NY
pros: As an employee at Iona College, you are entitled to tuition remission. Saves a lot of money if you want to go back to school.
cons: No one socializes, no room for growth, poor communication with management, no parking, and low salary which leads to low motivation.

review_title: Love the small community feel of the campus.
